name: PSR B1257+12
scenarioDescription:
The PSR B1257+12 Exoplanetary System

PSR B1257+12 is a star with 1.4 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.198 times its radius. It is located 1956.94 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 3 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

PSR B1257+12 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

PSR B1257+12 b

PSR B1257+12 b was discovered by the Arecibo Observatory observatory using the pulsar timing method. Its discovery was announced in 1994-04. Its semi-major axis is 0.19 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 25.26 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, PSR B1257+12.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0, which means that when PSR B1257+12 b is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.19 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.19. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of PSR B1257+12 b is 0.02 times the mass of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, PSR B1257+12 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

PSR B1257+12 c

PSR B1257+12 c was discovered by the Arecibo Observatory observatory using the pulsar timing method. Its discovery was announced in 1992-01. Its semi-major axis is 0.36 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 66.54 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, PSR B1257+12.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.0186, which means that when PSR B1257+12 c is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.35 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.37. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of PSR B1257+12 c is 4.30 times the mass of Earth. At 4.30 Earth masses, PSR B1257+12 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

PSR B1257+12 d

PSR B1257+12 d was discovered by the Arecibo Observatory observatory using the pulsar timing method. Its discovery was announced in 1992-01. Its semi-major axis is 0.46 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 98.21 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, PSR B1257+12.

The mass of PSR B1257+12 d is 3.90 times the mass of Earth. At 3.90 Earth masses, PSR B1257+12 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system PSR B1257+12, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Arecibo Observatory.
